    Discovery of a Highly Selective Tankyrase Inhibitor Displaying Growth Inhibition Effects against a Diverse Range of Tumor Derived Cell Lines

    Abstract

    The availability of high quality probes for specific protein targets is fundamental to the investigation of their function and their validation as therapeutic targets. We report the utilization of a dedicated chemoproteomic assay platform combining affinity enrichment technology with high-resolution protein mass spectrometry to the discovery of a novel nicotinamide isoster, the tetrazoloquinoxaline 41, a highly potent and selective tankyrase inhibitor. We also describe the use of 41 to investigate the biology of tankyrase, revealing the compound induced growth inhibition of a number of tumor derived cell lines, demonstrating the potential of tankyrase inhibitors in oncology.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Tankyrases (TNKS1 and TNKS2) belong to the family of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerases (PARPs) and share high sequence and structural identities. They have overlapping functions playing a role in a diverse range of cellular functions, which have been the subject of comprehensive reviews.(1-4) These functions include a role in telomere homeostasis,(5) vesicle translocation,(6, 7) proteosomal assembly,(8) mitosis,(9-11) myelination of cells in the oligodendrocyte lineage,(12, 13) mediation of insulin-stimulated glucose uptake,(6) and regulation of the Wnt/Î²-catenin pathway.(14-16) The relevance of a number of these pathways to cancer cell proliferation led to an increased interest in the discovery of new and selective TNKS inhibitors throughout academia and the drug discovery industry,(14, 17-30) and the discovery of TNKS inhibitors has been the subject of several excellent reviews.(1, 4, 31-34) TNKS inhibitors can be grouped into two categories. First, those that bind to the nicotinamide binding site, such as 1 (XAV939).(14) This compound was discovered in a phenotypic screening campaign searching for modulators of the Wnt/Î²-catenin signaling pathway and subsequently shown to mediate its effect through inhibition of TNKS. The second category of TNKS inhibitors is those that bind in the adenosine binding site inducing a shift in the D-loop. An example of this class of TNKS inhibitor is 4-((3aR,4S,7R,7aS)-1,3-dioxo-3a,4,7,7a-tetrahydro-1H-4,7-metha-noisoindol-2(3H)-yl)-N-(quinolin-8-yl)benzamide (IWR-1), which was also first discovered as an inhibitor of the Wnt/Î²-catenin signaling pathway in a phenotypic high throughput screen.(18, 35, 36) Finally, a set of dual-site TNKS inhibitors are described that simultaneously bind in both the nicotinamide and adenosine binding pockets, exemplified by the long quinazolinone series discovered by Bregman et al.(23) Using our chemoproteomics technology,(37-40) we discovered and characterized a selective tankyrase probe, which binds in the nicotinamide binding site, to aid in investigating the therapeutic potential of novel TNKS inhibitors.
    Chemoproteomic competition binding experiments enable the selectivity of a molecule to be determined against large sections of the proteome in a single experiment. Moreover, as cell or tissue extracts can be used as the protein source, this ensures close-to-physiological conditions as the assayed proteins are full length, post-translationally modified, and many proteinâprotein interactions remain intact. Together, this makes these experiments powerful tools in the discovery of drugs and probes, as we recently described for the discovery of a selective PI3KÎ³ probe.(37) These experiments require the generation of an affinity matrix, by the immobilization of inhibitors on a polymer resin, that specifically binds to the target class of interest (for example, kinases(37, 38, 40) or HDACs(39)). The binding affinity of a test compound for these proteins is determined in a competition binding assay, measuring the concentration-dependent decrease of target protein binding to the matrix in the presence of the test compound. Quantitative mass spectrometry analysis enables the determination of the binding affinity of the free compound for all proteins specifically captured by the matrix in that given experiment. Mass spectrometry-based-competition binding assays represent a powerful method for determining compound selectivity, but it is costly and has a relativity low throughput. Thus, only a limited number of compounds can be analyzed within the time frame required for a drug discovery program. To support lead optimization programs, the throughput can be increased by using a spot array format coupled to antibody-based detection. In this case, the abundance of the matrix captured target protein is determined using a specific antibody after automated spotting of the proteins eluted from the affinity matrix on a membrane.(37) In this format, large numbers of compounds can be tested within a short time frame; however, the binding affinity determination is limited by the availability of a specific antibody and is only feasible for the target protein or a limited set of proteins within the time scale required.
    In this report, we describe the discovery and characterization of tetrazoloquinoxaline 41, a highly potent and selective tankyrase inhibitor, using a chemoproteomics approach.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    We established a chemoproteomics-based strategy that not only enables the high throughput screening of compounds for binding to TNKS1 in HeLa cell extracts via antibody-based detection (referred to as TNKS-array-assay), but also the determination of the selectivity of the compounds against a large section of the PARP family via mass spectrometry (MS) detection (referred to as TNKS-MS-assay). To achieve this, we immobilized known PARP inhibitors on a cross-linked agarose bead (see Supporting Information for full details), analogous to our work on the development of kinobeads previously described.(38) Jurkat cells express many of the PARP family members,(41) and consequently, Jurkat lysate was selected as the protein source. This affinity matrix specifically captured up to 10 PARP family members including TNKS1 and TNKS2. Consistent with previous Jurkat cell expression profiling data, PARP3, 6, 7, and 15 were not identified in these experiments.(41) Additionally, PARP8, 9, and 12 which are reported to be expressed in Jurkat cells were also not identified, indicating that they do not bind to the immobilized inhibitors. Although the ligands we utilized to generate our matrix do not interact with the nicotinamide binding site of PARP13,(42) PARP13 was nonetheless identified in these experiments. It is likely that PARP13 binds indirectly to the affinity matrix through a complex partner. Non-lactame mimetics of nicotinamides have previously been successfully exploited as TNKS inhibitors, and in a preliminary experiment, we used this matrix to determine the PARP family binding selectivity for two examples of TNKS inhibitors, compounds 1(14) and 2,(28) which bind in the nicotinamide pocket (Figure 1 and Supporting Information, Table S3). These results reveal that compound 1, a commonly used TNKS reference inhibitor, not only binds with high affinity to TNKS1 and TNKS2 but also binds PARP1, albeit with approximately 100-fold lower affinity. These data are consistent with that of a cellular thermal shift assay demonstrating that compound 1 engages PARP1 in HEK293 cells.(43) Compound 2 is a representative example from the series explored by Schultz et al.(28) in which they used lipophilic efficiency to drive their compound optimization. The TNKS-MS-assay revealed that compound 2 has greater selectivity over the other PARP family members detected, compared to compound 1. However, the binding affinity for TNKS1 and TNKS2 of compound 2 was determined to be slightly lower than that of compound 1 in the TNKS-MS-assay, and indeed, it was reported that this translated into a lower cellular potency in a Wnt-reporter assay.(28) This novel PARP selectivity assay could be utilized to generate novel TNKS inhibitors that combine exquisite selectivity with high cellular potency and could prove valuable in interrogating the biology of tankyrases.
    The TNKS-array-assay was used to screen a diverse set of about 62500 compounds for TNKS binding. The first screen was carried out at a single concentration of 40 Î¼M, with the exception of a set of fragment compounds, which were screened at final concentrations of 1 mM and 100 Î¼M. Compounds showing competition above 50% were followed up in a full doseâresponse experiment. A total of 59 molecules exhibited a pIC50 greater than 6, of which 13 had a pIC50 greater than 7. From these hits, the tetrazolo[1,5-a]quinoxaline series was selected for further SAR studies, as it was deemed to be the most promising series to achieve high selectivity for TNKS over other PARP family members.

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Following a previously reported procedure,(44) compounds 4-20 were synthesized in one step in acceptable yields via a SNAr reaction of the appropriately substituted aniline with 4-chlorotetrazolo[1, 5-a]quinoxaline 3 (Scheme 1). Compound 13 was subsequently transformed into compounds 21â24 and 26â32 via an amide coupling reaction with the appropriately substituted amine (Scheme 2). Compounds 25 and 33 were similarly prepared from 19 and 20, respectively (Scheme 2). Compounds 36â43 were synthesized as described in Scheme 3. The key intermediate 35 could be readily synthesized in large scale via the amide bond formation between 13 and tert-butyl piperazine-1-carboxylate, followed by the subsequent acidic-deprotection of the Boc-protected amine. Compounds 36â43 were prepared from 35 via a second amide coupling reaction with the appropiately substituted carboxylic acid or acid chloride.

    StructureâActivity Relationship

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The focus of our structureâactivity relationship (SAR) studies was to optimize TNKS potency (determined using TNKS-array-assay) and selectivity over any potential off-targets within the PARP family (determined using TNKS-MS-assay). It was concluded that the ideal molecule should be equally potent against both TNKS1 and TNKS2 because of their overlapping functions(1, 2) and the high degree of sequence and structural similarity. Moreover, in mouse model systems, genetic knockout of either TNKS1 or TNKS2 resulted in no overt phenotype. On the other hand, the double knockout of both genes resulted in an embryonic lethal phenotype,(45) suggesting a level of functional redundancy between the two gene products. It was also vital that the potencies measured with our in vitro assays correlated with those determined in cellular assays. Another important set of parameters that required optimization were the physicalâchemical properties of the molecules to improve ADMET profiles.(46-49) In this instance, one key property we looked to improve through optimization of the physicalâchemical properties was the aqueous solubility, and this was monitored throughout.
    Initial optimization focused on phenyl ring d (Table 1). Replacement with either a saturated cycle or heteroaromatic ring led to a substantial drop in potency (data not shown). Therefore, our efforts focused on optimization of the substitution pattern on the phenyl ring. Comparison of molecules 5, 6, and 7, where the phenyl ring is substituted with a methyl group in the ortho, meta, or para position, respectively, clearly reveals that only para substitution is tolerated. A number of moieties such as alkyl chains, halides, amines, nitriles, and amides retain activity at this position. However, substitution of the phenyl with these moieties did not give an increase in potency or solubility compared to that of the unsubstituted phenyl compound 4 and is therefore not advantageous. Nonetheless, profiling of 9 using the TNKS-MS-assay revealed excellent selectivity of this series for the TNKSs over other PARP family members (Figure 2 and Supporting Information, Table S3), supporting further optimization efforts. Introduction of the tertiary amide substituent provided a breakthrough, as shown by the 25-fold greater TNKS1 potency of compound 16 compared to that of compound 4. Comparison of compound 16 with the dimethyl amine 14, which is substantially less potent, highlights the importance of the carbonyl moiety. However, compound 16 still had poor solubility. The introduction of cyclic amide led to compound 18 with good potency against TNKS1 (pIC50 8.1) and slightly improved solubility. The para substituted reverse amides (21 to 24, and 35) were also potent, and in this amide class, an even larger difference between the secondary and tertiary amide analogues was observed. This is illustrated by the comparison of 21 and 22 where the potency increases 10-fold by methylation of the nitrogen. Compound 23 containing a morpholine amide gave a good balance of potency and solubility. Its TNKS-MS-assay profile (Figure 2 and Supporting Information, Table S3) revealed that this molecule was again selective for TNKS1 against the other PARPs identified in this experiment. Interestingly, amides are not tolerated at the meta position (compound 33). Moreover, further substitution of the phenyl ring containing the para amide even with a small group such as fluorine (compound 25) results in a large drop in activity, confirming the very tight SAR around this phenyl ring.
    Table 1. Assay Data for Compounds 4â18, 21â25, 33, and 35a
    Table a

    n.d.: not determined.

    Further optimization efforts were greatly aided by the generation of an X-ray cocrystal structure of 23 in TNKS2. Analysis of this revealed that the inhibitor was tightly bound within the nicotinamide binding pocket forming a number of Ï-interactions with the side chains of Tyr1071 and Tyr1060. One nitrogen of the tetrazole and the NH linking rings b and d form a pair of hydrogen bonding interactions to the backbone NH and carbonyl of Gly1032 (Figure 3). Additionally, another of the tetrazole nitrogen atoms is within hydrogen bonding distance of the side chain of Ser1068. This binding mode, hydrogen bonds, as well as the Ï-interactions are common features in X-ray cocrystal structures of inhibitors binding in this pocket.(50, 51) We hoped to get insights from the crystal structure on how to replace or modify the tetrazolo[1,5a]quinoxaline core, clearly the root cause of the poor physicochemical properties. Unfortunately, all attempts to modify the core, including further substitution or full removal of ring a, led to a loss in potency (see data shown in Supporting Information, Table S1). It was therefore decided to leave the tetrazolo[1,5a]quinoxaline core unaltered in further SAR studies. The crystal structure revealed one position for further optimization, namely, substitution of the morpholine. Although the morpholine points in the direction of solvent, it is still within the binding pocket; therefore, growing the molecule in this direction could pick up further interactions with the protein leading to an increase in potency. At the same time, this substitution could be used as a handle to improve physicalâchemical properties. With respect to this, a series of analogues where the morpholine was replaced with a piperazine were synthesized (shown in Table 2).
    Table 2. Assay Data for Compounds 26â32 and 36â43
    Substitution of the piperazine with an aliphatic straight chain (43) or cyclic amide (26, 36) showed only a slight increase in potency compared to that of the unsubstituted piperazine 35. On the other hand, substitution of the piperazine with a heteroaromatic amide gave a substantial increase in potency. The imidazole (38, 41, and 42) and pyrazole (39 and 40) amides were particularly potent, and this was coupled to a desirable increase in solubility. An interesting comparison of imidazole 38 and its N-methylated analogue 41 can be made. The TNKS1 binding of these molecules measured using TNKS-array-assay was very similar necessitating the use of a cellular assay for further discrimination. It has been reported that TNKS is important in the regulation of the Wnt/Î²-catenin signaling pathway and that TNKS inhibition leads to subsequent inhibition of this pathway.(14) Therefore, monitoring the Wnt-dependent increase of Î²-catenin using a luciferase reporter assay was used to determine the cellular potency of compounds. Interestingly, compound 41 was determined to be about 10-fold more potent than 38 in the cell based Wnt-reporter assay, presumably due to increased cell permeation. Compound 42, the regioisomer of compound 41, has 10-fold less binding affinity for TNKS1. This could be due to the methyl at this position causing a steric clash with the protein or the imidazole now being locked in less active conformation. Molecules 28â32, with the piperazine substituted directly with a heteroaromatic, also had excellent binding affinity for TNKS1. The pyrimidines 31 and 32 stood out because of their excellent cellular activity in the Wnt reporter assay, although this is counterbalanced by their lower solubility.
    Because of its excellent balance of high potency against TNKS1 and good solubility compound 41 was selected for further profiling to allow a greater understanding of whether it could be used as a probe molecule. Although its low solubility could hinder its further progression, compound 32 was also further profiled as it showed outstanding cellular potency.
    The pIC50 of 32 and 41 was determined to be 7.8 and 7.5 in an in vitro enzymatic assay, monitoring the PARsylation of Axin2 by a TNKS1 construct. This confirmed that the binding to TNKS1 measured in the TNKS-array-assay translated into inhibition of its catalytic activity. In a corresponding assay with a PARP1 construct, 41 displayed no inhibition (pIC50 < 5.7) of its catalytic activity. To further explore the selectivity of 32 and 41, they were profiled in the TNKS-MS-assay. This revealed that both compounds have a greater than 500-fold selectivity window over other PARPs identified in the experiment with no residual binding up to the highest concentration (5 Î¼M) used in the assay (Figure 2 and Supporting Information, Table S3). To broaden the proteomic-based selectivity profiling of compounds 32 and 41 beyond the PARP family, their analogue 35 was immobilized on cross-linked agarose beads through the secondary amine, and affinity enrichment chemoproteomics experiments were performed in Jurkat cell lysates. The exquisite selectivity of 32 and 41 was confirmed in these experiments. TNKS1 and TNKS2 as well as two reported interactors(52, 53) were the only proteins specifically captured and competed (Supporting Information, Table S4). The two interacting proteins, GMDS (GDP-mannose-4, 6-dehydratase) and SSSCA1 (Sjoegren syndrome/scleroderma autoantigen 1), show affinities similar to those determined for the TNKSs suggesting that they were indeed captured indirectly in a complex with TNKS1 and/or TNKS2. Compounds 32 and 41 were also profiled against a diverse panel of selected assays designed to identify potential liabilities of a compound (Supporting Information, Tables S5 and S6). In these assays, compound 32 exhibited weak activity against only PI3KÎ³ (pIC50 4.5), whereas compound 41 showed weak activity against hERG (pEC50 4.4), PDE3A (pIC50 4.3), and OATP1B1 (pIC50 4.4) and was also a weak blocker of serotonin 3 and Î±1 nicotinic AchR (pEC50 4.6 and 4.7, respectively). Although these identified liabilities could pose a severe threat for the progression of a potential drug candidate, the large selectivity window for TNKS over any off-target identified allows the further progression of this molecule as a probe molecule. A single dose rat pharmacokinetics study was carried out for both molecules (see Supporting Information, Table S7). This revealed that both compounds have a low volume of distribution that prevented their progression into in vivo xenograft studies. Nonetheless, both compounds represent excellent in vitro tools to further explore the biology of TNKS and will prove to be valuable additions to the available selection of TNKS inhibitors.

    Assessment of 41 in Cell Growth Inhibition Assays

    TNKS plays a role in a diverse range of cellular functions relevant to cancer cell proliferation.(4) Indeed, other studies have investigated the potential for tankyrase inhibitors as anticancer agents.(3, 32, 54) These investigations were carried out in a variety of model systems and induced their effect by directly inhibiting cancer cell growth,(14, 55-57) rendering cancer cells more sensitive to other chemotherapeutic agents,(58-62) or altering cell migration characteristics.(63, 64) However, most of the studies evaluating the effects of tankyrase inhibition on cell growth have been limited to a small number of cell lines. We evaluated the effects of 41 on the growth of a diverse set of 40 tumor-derived cell lines, representing all major tissue types of origin (lung, breast, colon, liver, brain, and kidney). This approach will aid comparative analyses aimed at understanding the basis of cell sensitivity versus cell resistance to tankyrase inhibition. For example, the tankyrase inhibitor 1 was shown to inhibit colony formation in DLD-1 cells (Î²-catenin-dependent) but not in RKO cells (Î²-catenin-independent).(14) Our panel of cell lines, tested in parallel under standardized conditions, will allow extension of these types of correlations to a larger set of biological samples. We profiled the cell lines with a full dose range of 41 (10 Î¼M maximal dose) over a 6-day time course. Cellular ATP levels, as measured by the Cell-Titer Glo assay (Promega), were used as a surrogate of viable cells present in each sample, and data from the 6-day 41-treated samples were compared to DMSO-control treated samples from day 1 (t = 0). Since earlier reports indicated that tankyrase inhibitors are more efficacious in media with lower serum,(56) we evaluated 41 in media containing both 10% and 1% FBS.
    Compound 41 exhibited greater than 50% inhibition of cell growth with submicromolar potency in 30 cell lines cultured in either 1% or 10% FBS (Table 3). Examples of two sensitive cell lines (A704 and NCI-H292) are shown in Figure 4. Consistent with previous reports, cells treated in 1% FBS were generally more sensitive to growth inhibition by 41. The potency of compound 41 varied from approximately 20 nM to 600 nM, with the most sensitive cell lines resulting in growth IC50s in the range of 20 to 30 nM. Interestingly, we did not observe any striking correlation between the tissue origin of the cell lines in our broad panel and sensitivity to compound 41. Additionally, using publicly available mutation data,(65, 66) we did not observe a correlation between the presence of Wnt pathway mutations or mutations that predict sensitivity to PARP inhibitors (BRCA1/2 mutations) and sensitivity to compound 41 (Table 3). However, our characterized panel provides a resource for follow-up analyses based on genetic, mutational, or bioinformatic approaches and will become more relevant as large data sets of genome-wide sequence information in cancer cell lines become available.(67) This could help reveal the molecular underpinnings of tankyrase sensitivity as well as other targets and pathways involved in the response. This could in turn have potential clinical implications in oncology with regard to treatment strategy and patient stratification.

    Conclusion

    We identified the tetrazoloquinoxaline core as a promising new chemotype for the rational design of highly selective TNKS1 and TNKS2 inhibitors that represent excellent probes for the interrogation of tankyrase biology. Greatly aided by X-ray crystallography, which confirmed binding in the nicotinamide pocket, our lead optimization efforts mainly focused on improving on-target potency, selectivity, and solubility. This culminated in the discovery of compound 41, with good solubility and high on-target potency, which correlates well with cellular activity. One of the most important quality criteria for probes is their selectivity. Throughout the whole optimization process, the selectivity of compounds was monitored using our chemoproteomics MS platform. For this purpose, we developed a new affinity matrix for a subset of the PARP protein family in analogy to our well established kinobeads technology. In support of its use as a molecular probe for TNKS1/2, compound 41 does not show any residual activity against 8 other PARP enzymes identified. This increases the confidence that the observed effect is driven by inhibition of the target and not any off-target effects. The in vitro properties of 41 are comparable to the best TNKS inhibitors previously reported and could prove a valuable addition to the exploration of TNKS biology.
    We went on to demonstrate that compound 41 had substantial growth inhibitory effects in specific tumor-derived cell lines, consistent with its biological role in inhibiting the Tankyrase enzymesâ activity. Given the complex functions of the tankyrases in cell signaling pathways, the specific properties of an inhibitor required to increase efficacy and reduce toxicity in a specific disease context in the clinic still need to be determined. The excellent TNKS selectivity of compound 41 over the other PARP family members provides an additional probe from a unique chemotype to further explore these aspects of tankyrase biology.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Compound Synthesis: General

    Unless otherwise stated, all solvents and chemicals like the building block 4-chlorotetrazolo[1,5-a]quinoxaline (3) were used as purchased without further purification. For separation of DCM and aqueous layers during sample workup, Radleys Phase Separation 6 mL Columns (RR99821) were used. Preparative high performance liquid chromatography (prep. HPLC) was performed on a waters autopurification system [2767 Sample manager, 2545 Binary Gradient Module, 2420 ELS Detector, 2996 Photodiode Array Detector, 3100 Mass Detector, Waters SFO, and Waters 515 HPLC Pump]. The purification was done on a XBridge BEH C18 OBD 5 Î¼m Prep Column using a water/acetonitrile mixture (0.2% formic acid as modifier) at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The purity of all final compounds was 95% or higher as determined by ultraperformance liquid chromatography (LC MS), photodiode array detection. The instrument used for analysis was a Waters Acquity system [detectors: Acquity SQD, Acquity ELSD, Acquity PDA] with a Waters ACQUITY UPLC BEH C18 1.7 Î¼m column. The analysis was performed at a flow rate of 1 mL/min with a linear gradient over 2 min (3 to 99% acetonitrile in water, 0.1% formic acid as modifier). Proton (1H) NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 400 spectrometer (400 MHz) using DMSO-d6 or CDCl3 as solvents. Chemical shifts are given in parts per million (ppm) (Î´ relative to residual solvent peak for 1H).

    TNKS-Array-Assay

    The TNKS1 assay is based on chemoproteomics affinity-enrichment technology and is performed in a 384-well format using an antibody based read-out. The affinity matrix was prepared as described in Supporting Information and consists of 17.5:17.5:1 (Rucaparib/PJ34 analogue/Bisindolylmaleimide VIII). For the assays, 0.375 mg of HeLa cell extract with a protein concentration of 7.5 mg/mL in lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl [pH 7.4], 5% glycerol, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 150 mM NaCl, 25 mM NaF, 1 mM Na3VO4, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 0.8% Igepal-CA630, and a protease inhibitor cocktail) and 0.75 Î¼L capturing matrix per well (final volume 75 Î¼L in well) were incubated in the absence or presence of test compound at 4 Â°C for 2 h. Each plate contained 15 positive (5 Î¼M compound 1) and 17 negative (2% DMSO) controls. The final compound concentration in the single concentration experiments was 40 Î¼M, with the exception of a fragment compound set (final assay concentration of 1 mM and 100 Î¼M). Compounds were tested in a concentrationâresponse format with a starting concentration of 200 Î¼M applying 1:3 dilution steps for, in total, 10 data points. DMSO concentration was 2%. After incubation, the nonbound fraction was removed by washing the beads with buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl [pH 7.5], 0.4% Igepal-CA630, 5% glycerol, 150 mM NaCl, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 25 mM NaF, 1 mM Na3VO4, and 1 mM dithiothreitol). Proteins retained on the beads were eluted in SDS buffer (100 mM Tris [pH 7.4], 4% SDS, 20% glycerol, 0.01% bromophenol blue, and 50 mM dithiothreitol) and spotted on nitrocellulose membranes (400 nl per spot) using an automated pin-tool liquid transfer (Biomek FX, Beckman). After drying, the membranes were rehydrated in 20% ethanol and processed for detection by overnight incubation at 4 Â°C with a specific anti-TNKS1 antibody (Santa Cruz, sc-8337; (1:400) in the presence of 0.4% Tween), followed by incubation for 1 h at room temperature with an IRDye 800-labeled secondary antibody for visualization (antirabbit 926-32211, LICOR (1:5000) in the presence of 0.2% Tween). Spot intensities were quantified using a LiCOR Odyssey scanner. All active compounds from the high throughput screen were examined for known assay interference motifs(68) and found not to contain any.

    TNKS-MS-Assay

    A dilution series of test inhibitor (starting at 5 Î¼M, applying 1:4 dilution steps for a total 10 data points) was incubated 45 min at 4 Â°C in 0.4 mg Jurkat cell extract (with a protein concentration of 5 mg/mL) in lysis buffer (50 mM Tris/HCl [pH 7.4], 5% glycerol, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 150 mM NaCl, 25 mM NaF, 1 mM Na3VO4, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 0.8% Igepal-CA630, and a protease inhibitor cocktail). 2.625 Î¼L of affinity matrix (prepared as described in Supporting Information and consisting of 17.5:17.5:1 (Rucaparib/PJ34 analogue/Bisindolylmaleimide VIII) was added and incubated for 1 h at 4 Â°C. The nonbound fraction was removed by washing the beads with lysis buffer. Bound proteins were eluted in LDS sample buffer (Invitrogen) supplemented with DTT, and proteins were alkylated with iodoacetamide. The eluted proteins were concentrated on NuPAGE 4â12% Bis-Tris Midi gels (Invitrogen) by running samples approximately 2 cm into the gel. After staining with colloidal Coomassie, gel lanes were cut into three slices covering the entire separation range (â¼2 cm) and subjected to in-gel trypsin digestion.(38) Peptide samples were then labeled with 10-plex TMT (TMT10, Thermo Fisher Scientific) reagents, enabling relative quantification.(69) The labeling reaction was performed in 40 mM triethylammoniumbicarbonate, pH 8.5 at 22 Â°C, and quenched with glycine. Labeled peptide extracts were combined to a single sample per compound. Combined samples were then dried in vacuo and resuspended in 0.05% trifluoroacetic acid in water and injected into an Ultimate3000 nanoRLSC (Dionex, Sunnyvale, CA) coupled to a Q-Exactive (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Peptides were separated on custom 50 cm Ã 100 Î¼M (ID) reversed-phase columns (Reprosil) at 40 Â°C. Gradient elution was performed from 2% to 40% acetonitrile in 0.1% formic acid over 2 h. Samples were online injected into a Q-Exactive mass spectrometer operating with a data-dependent top 10 method. MS spectra were acquired by using 70.000 resolution and an ion target of 3E6. Higher energy collisional dissociation (HCD) scans were performed with 35% NCE at 35.000 resolution (at m/z 200), and the ion target setting was set to 2E5 so as to avoid coalescence.(70) The instruments were operated with Tune 2.2 or 2.3 and Xcalibur 2.7 or 3.0.63. Peptides were identified and quantified, and protein pIC50s determined as described in the Supporting Information.

    Affinity Enrichment Chemoproteomic Profiling of 32 and 41

    Jurkat cells extracts (5 mg/mL protein) in assay buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl [pH 7.4], 5% glycerol, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM Na3VO4, 25 mM NaF, and 1 mM dithiothreitol) containing 0.4% Igepal-CA630 were incubated for 1 h at 4 Â°C with either 35 Î¼L of affinity matrix (2-aminoethan-1-ol or compound 35 coupled to NHS-activated sepharose at 20 or 0.2 mM, respectively) or 5 Î¼L of compound (32 or 41, full dose range with 5 Î¼M maximal concentration). Supernatants from the affinity matrix incubation and the compound/lysate mix were transferred separately to plates containing 35 Î¼L of affinity matrix (compound 35 coupled to NHS-activated sepharose at 0.2 mM). This was incubated for 1 h at 4 Â°C with overhead rotation. The affinity matrix was collected and washed with assay buffer containing 0.4% Igepal-CA630 and subsequently with assay buffer containing 0.2% Igepal-CA630. Bound proteins were eluted by the addition of 50 Î¼L of 2Ã LDS sample buffer (Thermo Fisher Scientific #NP0007) containing 50 mM DTT and incubating for 30 min at 50 Â°C with shaking (140 rpm). Eluted proteins were processed and then identified and quantified by mass spectrometry as described above for the TNKS-MS-assay.

    Wnt/Î²-Catenin Reporter Gene Assay

    HEK293 cells (DSMZ, Braunschweig, Germany) were transfected with a TCF/LEF luciferase reporter plasmid (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) using the TransIT-LT1 reagent (Mirus Biosciences, Madison, WI) in DMEM medium (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA) supplemented with 2% FBS (Life Technologies) overnight. After medium removal, cells were preincubated with compounds or vehicle (0.5% DMSO) for 1 h in fresh DMEM medium containing 10% FBS and stimulated with human recombinant Wnt-3a ligand (R&D, Minneapolis, MN) and R-spondin 1 (R&D) for 24 h. Reporter luminescence was detected using a Bright Glo luciferase kit (Promega, Madison, WI) on a plate reader (Envision, PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA).

    TNKS Enzymatic Assay

    The reaction buffer used in this assay was 50 mM HEPES (pH 7) containing 1 mM CHAPS, and the detection buffer was 50 mM HEPES containing 0.1% BSA, 0.8 M KF, and 20 mM EDTA. Compound 32 or 41 was incubated with 8 nM His-tankyrase 1 (1091â1325) in 5 Î¼L of reaction buffer for 30 min at room temperature in a black flat bottomed low volume 384 well plate (Greiner). To this was then added 5 Î¼L of reaction buffer containing 0.2 mM NAD, 50 nM GST-tev-Axin2 (1â280), and 10 mM MnCl2, and this was incubated for 2 h at room temperature. Finally, 10 Î¼L of 25 nM anti-GST-d2, 1 nM anti-PAR, and 10 mM nicotinamide prepared in detection buffer was added, and this was incubated for 1 h at room temperature. The plates were then read on a plate reader (Envision, PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA).

    PARP1 Enzymatic Assay

    The reaction buffer used in this assay was 50 mM HEPES (pH 7.5), containing 1 mM CHAPS, 5 mM DTT, 0.1% BSA, 10 mM NaCl, and 0.002 mg/mL activated DNA, and the detection buffer was 50 mM HEPES (pH 7), containing 0.1% BSA, 0.8 M KF, and 20 mM EDTA. Compound 41 was incubated with 5 Î¼L of reaction buffer containing 0.2 nM human PARP1 for 30 min at room temperature in a black flat bottomed low volume 384 well plate (Greiner). To this was then added 5 Î¼L of the reaction buffer containing 40 Î¼M NAD, 40 nM biotin-histone, and 50 mM MgCl2, and this was incubated for 1 h. Finally, 10 Î¼L of the detection buffer was added containing 0.2 mM nicotinamide, 0.04 Î¼M streptavidin XL665, and 1 nM anti-PAR, and this was incubated for 1 h. The plates were then read on a plate reader (Envision, PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA).

    Crystallography

    Residues 937 to 1166 of human TNKS2 were subcloned into pET24 with an N-terminal FLAG-6His purification tag and a TEV cleavage site. Protein was expressed and purified as previously described.(50) To generate apo crystals, 25 Î¼g of sequencing grade chymotrypsin was added to 5 mg of TNKS2 in 1 mL of storage buffer (25 mM HEPES, 250 mM NaCl pH 7.5, and 5% glycerol) and incubated on ice for â¼24 h. Crystals were obtained by hanging drop vapor diffusion at 22Â° in droplets consisting of 0.2 Î¼L of protein and 0.2 Î¼L of 1.4â1.6 M Na/KPO4 (pH 8.2). Crystals grew to maximum size within 3 days and were then soaked with â¼1 mM inhibitor for â¼3 days. Crystals were flash frozen in paraffin oil prior to data collection. Diffraction data were collected to 2.2 Ã resolution at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National laboratories on beamline LS-CAT 21ID-G and processed with XDS.(71) The structure was solved by molecular replacement using Molrep(72) and RCSB:3P0P as the starting model. The structure was built using Coot(73) and refined with Refmac.(73) Refinement statistics can be found in Supporting Information, Table S2. Coordinates have been deposited in the RCSB as 5DCZ.

    Cell Growth Inhibition Assay

    The authors gratefully acknowledge and thank the suppliers and depositors of cell lines (full list is given in Supporting Information, Table S8). Cell lines were thawed into T-175 flasks (Corning) in RPMI Medium 1640 (Gibco 22400â071) plus 10% FBS (Gibco) and 1Ã sodium pyruvate (Gibco). Cells were cultured for at least 1 week at 37 Â°C and 5% CO2, passaging via the SelecT automated cell culture system (Sartorius Stedim Biotech) until cell numbers were sufficient to seed assay plates. Suspension cell lines were harvested by transfer of cells, and adherent cell lines were harvested by aspirating the medium and treatment with 0.25% Trypsin-EDTA (Gibco). Cells were centrifuged for 10 min at 1000 rpm, and then each line was resuspended in sufficient media to seed 1000 cells in 45 Î¼L per well in two 384-well plates (Greiner), using a Multidrop Dispenser (ThermoFisher). For each cell type, two full plates were prepared: a time-zero plate for baseline and a test plate for compound treatments. Cells were then incubated overnight at 37 Â°C and 5% CO2. The next day, 45 Î¼L of CellTiter-Glo (Promega G7573) was added to each time-zero plate via Multidrop and incubated for 15 min at room temperature. Plates were then read on an LJL Analyst HT (LJL Biosystems; 500 ms integration time). Cells on each test plate were treated via a Biomek FX Liquid Handling system (Beckman Coulter) with 10 compounds, and positive and negative controls in parallel (Taxol and DMSO, respectively), all in triplicate 11-point serial dilution series. All wells on each plate had a final total volume of 50 Î¼L and a final concentration of 0.1% DMSO. Plates were then sealed with Breathe-Easy gas-permeable plate sealing membranes (Research Products International). Cells on the test plates were then incubated for 6 days at 37 Â°C and 5% CO2. After 6 days, 50 Î¼L of CellTiter-Glo was added to each well of the test plate using Multidrop, incubated for 15 min at room temperature, and read on an LJL Analyst HT. Relative cell numbers were thereby determined by luminescence detection of the cellsâ ATP content. The resulting data were expressed as a percentage of the number of cells present in the time-zero plate at the time of compound addition (T = 0), with the T = 0 value set as 100%. In Table 3, pGIC50s were calculated using the formula [âlog10(GIC50)], and the mean pGIC50 of triplicate values is presented. In cases where the GIC50 of a replicate was greater than the highest concentration of 41 used (10 Î¼M), the pGIC50 was assigned a value of 5 for the purposes of calculating the mean value. The cancer cell line panel was cross-referenced with publicly available mutation data from both CCLE(65) and The Sanger Institute(66) data sets, and while Wnt pathway mutations or mutations that predict sensitivity to PARP inhibitors (e.g., BRCA1/2) were present in a subset of cell lines, there did not appear to be an obvious correlation with sensitivity to compound 41. The genes that were evaluated included APC, Axin1, Axin2, BRCA1, BRCA2, CTNNB1, CREBBP/CBP, FAM123B/WTX, GSK3b, LRP5, LRP6, TCF7L1(TCF3), TCF7L2(TCF4).

      Tankyrases as drug targets
      Lehtio Lari; Chi Nai-Wen; Krauss Stefan
      The FEBS journal (2013), 280 (15), 3576-93 ISSN:.
      Tankyrase 1 and tankyrase 2 are poly(ADP-ribosyl)ases that are distinguishable from other members of the enzyme family by the structural features of the catalytic domain, and the presence of a sterile Î±-motif multimerization domain and an ankyrin repeat protein-interaction domain. Tankyrases are implicated in a multitude of cellular functions, including telomere homeostasis, mitotic spindle formation, vesicle transport linked to glucose metabolism, Wnt-Î²-catenin signaling, and viral replication. In these processes, tankyrases interact with target proteins, catalyze poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation, and regulate protein interactions and stability. The proposed roles of tankyrases in disease-relevant cellular processes have made them attractive drug targets. Recently, several inhibitors have been identified. The selectivity and potency of these small molecules can be rationalized by how they fit within the NAD(+)-binding groove of the catalytic domain. Some molecules bind to the nicotinamide subsite, such as generic diphtheria toxin-like ADP-ribosyltransferase inhibitors, whereas others bind to a distinct adenosine subsite that diverges from other diphtheria toxin-like ADP-ribosyltransferases and confers specificity. A highly potent dual-site inhibitor is also available. Within the last few years, tankyrase inhibitors have proved to be useful chemical probes and potential lead compounds, especially for specific cancers.

      Tankyrase function at telomeres, spindle poles, and beyond
      Hsiao, Susan J.; Smith, Susan
      Biochimie (2008), 90 (1), 83-92CODEN: BICMBE; ISSN:0300-9084. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Telomeres have special needs; they require distinct mechanisms for their protection, replication, and sepn. at mitosis. A dedicated six-subunit protein complex termed shelterin attends to these needs. But shelterin cannot do it alone and often relies on recruits from other cellular locales. One such recruit is tankyrase 1, a poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase that is brought to telomeres by the shelterin DNA binding subunit TRF1, where it functions in telomere length regulation and sister chromatid sepn. An understanding of how tankyrase 1 functions at telomeres has been confounded by its complexity; it localizes to multiple subcellular sites, it has many diverse binding partners, and it has a closely related homolog (tankyrase 2) with which it may functionally overlap. This review summarizes our current knowledge of tankyrases focusing on their localization, binding partners, and function.

      Tankyrases: Structure, Function and Therapeutic Implications in Cancer
      Haikarainen, Teemu; Krauss, Stefan; Lehtio, Lari
      Current Pharmaceutical Design (2014), 20 (41), 6472-6488CODEN: CPDEFP; ISSN:1381-6128. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Several cellular signaling pathways are regulated by ADP-ribosylation, a posttranslational modification catalyzed by members of the ARTD superfamily. Tankyrases are distinguishable from the rest of this family by their unique domain organization, notably the sterile alpha motif responsible for oligomerization and ankyrin repeats mediating protein-protein interactions. Tankyrases are involved in various cellular functions, such as telomere homeostasis, Wnt/Î² -catenin signaling, glucose metab., and cell cycle progression. In these processes, Tankyrases regulate the interactions and stability of target proteins by poly (ADP-ribosyl)ation. Modified proteins are subsequently recognized by the E3 ubiquitin ligase RNF146, poly-ubiquitinated and predominantly guided to 26S proteasomal degrdn. Several small mol. inhibitors have been described for Tankyrases; they compete with the co-substrate NAD+ for binding to the ARTD catalytic domain. The recent, highly potent and selective inhibitors possess several properties of lead compds. and can be used for proof-of-concept studies in cancer and other Tankyrase linked diseases.

      Tankyrase-targeted therapeutics: expanding opportunities in the PARP family
      Riffell, Jenna L.; Lord, Christopher J.; Ashworth, Alan
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2012), 11 (12), 923-936CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. The poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) protein superfamily has wide-ranging roles in cellular processes such as DNA repair and WNT signalling. Efforts to pharmacol. target PARP enzymes have largely focused on PARP1 and the closely related PARP2, but recent work highlighting the role of another family member, tankyrase 1 (TANK1; also known as PARP5A and ARTD5), in the control of WNT signalling has fuelled interest in the development of addnl. inhibitors to target this enzyme class. We also consider the challenges that lie ahead for the clin. development of PARP family inhibitors in general.

      Tankyrase, a poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase at human telomeres
      Smith, Susan; Giriat, Izabela; Schmitt, Anja; De Langet, Titia
      Science (Washington, D. C.) (1998), 282 (5393), 1484-1488CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Tankyrase, a protein with homol. to ankyrins and to the catalytic domain of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP), was identified and localized to human telomeres. Tankyrase binds to the telomeric protein TRF1 (telomeric repeat binding factor-1), a neg. regulator of telomere length maintenance. Like ankyrins, tankyrase contains 24 ankyrin repeats in a domain responsible for its interaction with TRF1. Recombinant tankyrase was found to have PARP activity in vitro, with both TRF1 and tankyrase functioning as acceptors for ADP-ribosylation. ADP-ribosylation of TRF1 diminished its ability to bind to telomeric DNA in vitro, suggesting that telomere function in human cells is regulated by poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation.

      Tankyrase-1 polymerization of poly(ADP-ribose) is required for spindle structure and function
      Chang, Paul; Coughlin, Margaret; Mitchison, Timothy J.
      Nature Cell Biology (2005), 7 (11), 1133-1139CODEN: NCBIFN; ISSN:1465-7392. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Poly(ADP-ribose) (PAR) is a large, neg. charged post-translational modification that is produced by polymn. of NAD+ by PAR polymerases (PARPs). There are at least 18 PARPs in the human genome, several of which have functions that are unknown. PAR modifications are dynamic; PAR structure depends on the balance between synthesis and hydrolysis by PAR glycohydrolase. We previously found that PAR is enriched in vertebrate somatic-cell mitotic spindles and demonstrated a requirement for PAR in the assembly of Xenopus egg ext. spindles. Here, we knockdown all characterized PARPs using RNA interference (RNAi), and identify tankyrase-1 as the PARP that is required for mitosis. Tankyrase-1 localizes to mitotic spindle poles, to telomeres and to the Golgi app. Tankyrase-1 RNAi was recently shown to result in mitotic arrest, with abnormal chromosome distributions and spindle morphol. obsd. - data that is interpreted as evidence of post-anaphase arrest induced by failure of telomere sepn. We show that tankyrase-1 RNAi results in pre-anaphase arrest, with intact sister-chromatid cohesion. We also demonstrate a requirement for tankyrase-1 in the assembly of bipolar spindles, and identify the spindle-pole protein NuMA as a substrate for covalent modification by tankyrase-1.

      Axin2 as regulatory and therapeutic target in newborn brain injury and remyelination
      Fancy, Stephen P. J.; Harrington, Emily P.; Yuen, Tracy J.; Silbereis, John C.; Zhao, Chao; Baranzini, Sergio E.; Bruce, Charlotte C.; Otero, Jose J.; Huang, Eric J.; Nusse, Roel; Franklin, Robin J. M.; Rowitch, David H.
      Nature Neuroscience (2011), 14 (8), 1009-1016CODEN: NANEFN; ISSN:1097-6256. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Permanent damage to white matter tracts, comprising axons and myelinating oligodendrocytes, is an important component of brain injuries of the newborn that cause cerebral palsy and cognitive disabilities, as well as multiple sclerosis in adults. However, regulatory factors relevant in human developmental myelin disorders and in myelin regeneration are unclear. We found that AXIN2 was expressed in immature oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (OLPs) in white matter lesions of human newborns with neonatal hypoxic-ischemic and gliotic brain damage, as well as in active multiple sclerosis lesions in adults. The small mol. inhibitor XAV939, which targets the enzymic activity of tankyrase, acted to stabilize Axin2 levels in OLPs from brain and spinal cord and accelerated their differentiation and myelination after hypoxic and demyelinating injury. Together, these findings indicate that Axin2 is an essential regulator of remyelination and that it might serve as a pharmacol. checkpoint in this process.

      Tankyrase inhibition stabilizes axin and antagonizes Wnt signalling
      Huang, Shih-Min A.; Mishina, Yuji M.; Liu, Shanming; Cheung, Atwood; Stegmeier, Frank; Michaud, Gregory A.; Charlat, Olga; Wiellette, Elizabeth; Zhang, Yue; Wiessner, Stephanie; Hild, Marc; Shi, Xiaoying; Wilson, Christopher J.; Mickanin, Craig; Myer, Vic; Fazal, Aleem; Tomlinson, Ronald; Serluca, Fabrizio; Shao, Wenlin; Cheng, Hong; Shultz, Michael; Rau, Christina; Schirle, Markus; Schlegl, Judith; Ghidelli, Sonja; Fawell, Stephen; Lu, Chris; Curtis, Daniel; Kirschner, Marc W.; Lengauer, Christoph; Finan, Peter M.; Tallarico, John A.; Bouwmeester, Tewis; Porter, Jeffery A.; Bauer, Andreas; Cong, Feng
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2009), 461 (7264), 614-620CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The stability of the Wnt pathway transcription factor Î²-catenin is tightly regulated by the multi-subunit destruction complex. Deregulated Wnt pathway activity has been implicated in many cancers, making this pathway an attractive target for anticancer therapies. However, the development of targeted Wnt pathway inhibitors has been hampered by the limited no. of pathway components that are amenable to small mol. inhibition. Here, we used a chem. genetic screen to identify a small mol., XAV939, which selectively inhibits Î²-catenin-mediated transcription. Thus, our study provides new mechanistic insights into the regulation of axin protein homeostasis and presents new avenues for targeted Wnt pathway therapies.

      From Polypharmacology to Target Specificity: The Case of PARP Inhibitors
      Liscio, Paride; Camaioni, Emidio; Carotti, Andrea; Pellicciari, Roberto; Macchiarulo, Antonio
      Current Topics in Medicinal Chemistry (Sharjah, United Arab Emirates) (2013), 13 (23), 2939-2954CODEN: CTMCCL; ISSN:1568-0266. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Poly(ADP-ribose)polymerases (PARPs) catalyze a post-transcriptional modification of proteins, consisting in the attachment of mono, oligo or poly ADP-ribose units from NAD+ to specific polar residues of target proteins. The scientific interest in members of this superfamily of enzymes is continuously growing since they have been implicated in a range of diseases including stroke, cardiac ischemia, cancer, inflammation and diabetes. Despite some inhibitors of PARP-1, the founder member of the superfamily, have advanced in clin. trials for cancer therapy, and other members of PARPs have recently been proposed as interesting drug targets, challenges exist in understanding the polypharmacol. of current PARP inhibitors as well as developing highly selective chem. tools to unravel specific functions of each member of the superfamily. Beginning with an overview on the mol. aspects that affect polypharmacol., in this article we discuss how these may have an impact on PARP research and drug discovery. Then, we review the most selective PARP inhibitors hitherto reported in literature, giving an update on the mol. aspects at the basis of selective PARP inhibitor design. Finally, some outlooks on current issues and future directions in this field of research are also provided.

      New PARP targets for cancer therapy
      Vyas, Sejal; Chang, Paul
      Nature Reviews Cancer (2014), 14 (7), 502-509CODEN: NRCAC4; ISSN:1474-175X. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerases (PARPs) modify target proteins post-translationally with poly(ADP-ribose) (PAR) or mono(ADP-ribose) (MAR) using NAD+ as substrate. The best-studied PARPs generate PAR modifications and include PARP1 and the tankyrase PARP5A, both of which are targets for cancer therapy with inhibitors in either clin. trials or preclin. development. There are 15 addnl. PARPs, most of which modify proteins with MAR, and their biol. is less well understood. Recent data identify potentially cancer-relevant functions for these PARPs, which indicates that we need to understand more about these PARPs to effectively target them.

      Quantitative chemical proteomics reveals mechanisms of action of clinical ABL kinase inhibitors
      Bantscheff, Marcus; Eberhard, Dirk; Abraham, Yann; Bastuck, Sonja; Boesche, Markus; Hobson, Scott; Mathieson, Toby; Perrin, Jessica; Raida, Manfred; Rau, Christina; Reader, Valerie; Sweetman, Gavain; Bauer, Andreas; Bouwmeester, Tewis; Hopf, Carsten; Kruse, Ulrich; Neubauer, Gitte; Ramsden, Nigel; Rick, Jens; Kuster, Bernhard; Drewes, Gerard
      Nature Biotechnology (2007), 25 (9), 1035-1044CODEN: NABIF9; ISSN:1087-0156. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The authors describe a chem. proteomics approach to profile the interaction of small mols. with hundreds of endogenously expressed protein kinases and purine-binding proteins. This subproteome is captured by immobilized nonselective kinase inhibitors (kinobeads), and the bound proteins are quantified in parallel by mass spectrometry using isobaric tags for relative and abs. quantification (iTRAQ). By measuring the competition with the affinity matrix, the authors assess the binding of drugs to their targets in cell lysates and in cells. By mapping drug-induced changes in the phosphorylation state of the captured proteome, the authors also analyze signaling pathways downstream of target kinases. Quant. profiling of the drugs imatinib (Gleevec), dasatinib (Sprycel) and bosutinib in K562 cells confirms known targets including ABL and SRC family kinases and identifies the receptor tyrosine kinase DDR1 and the oxidoreductase NQO2 as novel targets of imatinib. The data suggest that the approach is a valuable tool for drug discovery.

      Wilhelm, Mathias; Schlegl, Judith; Hahne, Hannes; Gholami, Amin Moghaddas; Lieberenz, Marcus; Savitski, Mikhail M.; Ziegler, Emanuel; Butzmann, Lars; Gessulat, Siegfried; Marx, Harald; Mathieson, Toby; Lemeer, Simone; Schnatbaum, Karsten; Reimer, Ulf; Wenschuh, Holger; Mollenhauer, Martin; Slotta-Huspenina, Julia; Boese, Joos-Hendrik; Bantscheff, Marcus; Gerstmair, Anja; Faerber, Franz; Kuster, Bernhard

      Proteomes are characterized by large protein-abundance differences, cell-type- and time-dependent expression patterns and post-translational modifications, all of which carry biol. information that is not accessible by genomics or transcriptomics. Here we present a mass-spectrometry-based draft of the human proteome and a public, high-performance, in-memory database for real-time anal. of terabytes of big data, called ProteomicsDB. The information assembled from human tissues, cell lines and body fluids enabled estn. of the size of the protein-coding genome, and identified organ-specific proteins and a large no. of translated lincRNAs (long intergenic non-coding RNAs). Anal. of mRNA and protein-expression profiles of human tissues revealed conserved control of protein abundance, and integration of drug-sensitivity data enabled the identification of proteins predicting resistance or sensitivity. The proteome profiles also hold considerable promise for analyzing the compn. and stoichiometry of protein complexes. ProteomicsDB thus enables navigation of proteomes, provides biol. insight and fosters the development of proteomic technol.

      Structural Basis for Potency and Promiscuity in Poly(ADP-ribose) Polymerase (PARP) and Tankyrase Inhibitors
      Thorsell, Ann-Gerd; Ekblad, Torun; Karlberg, Tobias; Loew, Mirjam; Pinto, Ana Filipa; Tresaugues, Lionel; Moche, Martin; Cohen, Michael S.; Schuler, Herwig
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 60 (4), 1262-1271CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Selective inhibitors could help unveil the mechanisms by which inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerases (PARPs) elicits clin. benefits in cancer therapy. The authors profiled ten clin. PARP inhibitors and commonly used research tools for their inhibition of multiple PARP enzymes. The authors also detd. crystal structures of these compds. bound to PARP1 or PARP2. The authors' biochem. and structural anal. of PARP inhibitor potencies establishes a mol. basis for either selectivity or promiscuity and provides a benchmark for exptl. design in assessment of PARP inhibitor effects.

      Probing the links between in vitro potency, ADMET and physicochemical parameters
      Gleeson, M. Paul; Hersey, Anne; Montanari, Dino; Overington, John
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2011), 10 (3), 197-208CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. A common underlying assumption in current drug discovery strategies is that compds. with higher in vitro potency at their target(s) have greater potential to translate into successful, low-dose therapeutics. This has led to the development of screening cascades with in vitro potency embedded as an early filter. However, this approach is beginning to be questioned, given the bias in physicochem. properties that it can introduce early in lead generation and optimization, which is due to the often diametrically opposed relationship between physicochem. parameters assocd. with high in vitro potency and those assocd. with desirable absorption, distribution, metab., excretion and toxicity (ADMET) characteristics. Here, we describe analyses that probe these issues further using the ChEMBL database, which includes more than 500,000 drug discovery and marketed oral drug compds. Key findings include: first, that oral drugs seldom possess nanomolar potency (50 nM on av.); second, that many oral drugs have considerable off-target activity; and third, that in vitro potency does not correlate strongly with the therapeutic dose. These findings suggest that the perceived benefit of high in vitro potency may be negated by poorer ADMET properties.

      The role of ligand efficiency metrics in drug discovery
      Hopkins, Andrew L.; Keserue, Gyoergy M.; Leeson, Paul D.; Rees, David C.; Reynolds, Charles H.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2014), 13 (2), 105-121CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. The judicious application of ligand or binding efficiency metrics, which quantify the mol. properties required to obtain binding affinity for a drug target, is gaining traction in the selection and optimization of fragments, hits and leads. Retrospective anal. of recently marketed oral drugs shows that they frequently have highly optimized ligand efficiency values for their targets. Optimizing ligand efficiency metrics based on both mol. mass and lipophilicity, when set in the context of the specific target, has the potential to ameliorate the inflation of these properties that has been obsd. in current medicinal chem. practice, and to increase the quality of drug candidates.

      GDP-mannose-4,6-dehydratase is a cytosolic partner of tankyrase 1 that inhibits its poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase activity
      Bisht, Kamlesh K.; Dudognon, Charles; Chang, William G.; Sokol, Ethan S.; Ramirez, Alejandro; Smith, Susan
      Molecular and Cellular Biology (2012), 32 (15), 3044-3053CODEN: MCEBD4; ISSN:0270-7306. (American Society for Microbiology)
      Tankyrase 1 (I)is a poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) that participates in a broad range of cellular activities due to interaction with multiple binding partners. I recognizes a linear 6-residue degenerate motif and, hence, has hundreds of potential target proteins. The binding of partner proteins to I usually results in their poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation (PARsylation) and can lead to ubiquitination and proteasomal degrdn. However, it is not known how I PARP activity is regulated. Here, the authors identified GDP-mannose 4,6-dehydratase (II) as a binding partner of I. II is a cytosolic protein required for the 1st step of fucose synthesis. The authors showed that I was complexed with I in the cytosol throughout interphase, but that its assocn. with I was reduced upon entry into mitosis, when I binds to its other partners TRF1 (at telomeres) and NuMA (at spindle poles). In contrast to other binding partners, II was not PARsylated by I. Indeed, the authors showed that II inhibited I PARP activity in vitro, dependent on the II binding motif for I. In vivo, depletion of II led to degrdn. of I, dependent on the catalytic PARP activity of I. The authors speculated that the assocn. of I with II in the cytosol sequesters I in an inactive stable form that can be tapped by other target proteins as needed.

      The BioPlex Network: A Systematic Exploration of the Human Interactome
      Huttlin, Edward L.; Ting, Lily; Bruckner, Raphael J.; Gebreab, Fana; Gygi, Melanie P.; Szpyt, John; Tam, Stanley; Zarraga, Gabriela; Colby, Greg; Baltier, Kurt; Dong, Rui; Guarani, Virginia; Vaites, Laura Pontano; Ordureau, Alban; Rad, Ramin; Erickson, Brian K.; Wuhr, Martin; Chick, Joel; Zhai, Bo; Kolippakkam, Deepak; Mintseris, Julian; Obar, Robert A.; Harris, Tim; Artavanis-Tsakonas, Spyros; Sowa, Mathew E.; De Camilli, Pietro; Paulo, Joao A.; Harper, J.       Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2015), 162 (2), 425-440CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      Protein interactions form a network whose structure drives cellular function and whose organization informs biol. inquiry. Using high-throughput affinity-purifn. mass spectrometry, the authors identify interacting partners for 2594 human proteins in HEK293T cells. The resulting network (BioPlex) contains 23,744 interactions among 7668 proteins with 86% previously undocumented. BioPlex accurately depicts known complexes, attaining 80%-100% coverage for most CORUM complexes. The network readily subdivides into communities that correspond to complexes or clusters of functionally related proteins. More generally, network architecture reflects cellular localization, biol. process, and mol. function, enabling functional characterization of thousands of proteins. Network structure also reveals assocns. among thousands of protein domains, suggesting a basis for examg. structurally related proteins. Finally, BioPlex, in combination with other approaches, can be used to reveal interactions of biol. or clin. significance. For example, mutations in the membrane protein VAPB implicated in familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis perturb a defined community of interactors.

      Tankyrase inhibition impairs directional migration and invasion of lung cancer cells by affecting microtubule dynamics and polarity signals
      Lupo, Barbara; Vialard, Jorge; Sassi, Francesco; Angibaud, Patrick; Puliafito, Alberto; Pupo, Emanuela; Lanzetti, Letizia; Comoglio, Paolo M.; Bertotti, Andrea; Trusolino, Livio

      Background: Tankyrases are poly(ADP)-ribose polymerases that contribute to biol. processes as diverse as modulation of Wnt signaling, telomere maintenance, vesicle trafficking, and microtubule-dependent spindle pole assembly during mitosis. At interphase, polarized reshaping of the microtubule network fosters oriented cell migration. This is attained by assocn. of adenomatous polyposis coli with the plus end of microtubules at the cortex of cell membrane protrusions and microtubule-based centrosome reorientation towards the migrating front. Results: Here we report a new function for tankyrases, namely, regulation of directional cell locomotion. Using a panel of lung cancer cell lines as a model system, we found that abrogation of tankyrase activity by two different, structurally unrelated small-mol. inhibitors (one introduced and characterized here for the first time) or by RNA interference-based genetic silencing weakened cell migration, invasion, and directional movement induced by the motogenic cytokine hepatocyte growth factor. Mechanistically, the anti-invasive outcome of tankyrase inhibition could be ascribed to sequential deterioration of the distinct events that govern cell directional sensing. In particular, tankyrase blockade neg. impacted (1) microtubule dynamic instability; (2) adenomatous polyposis coli plasma membrane targeting; and (3) centrosome reorientation. Conclusions: Collectively, these findings uncover an unanticipated role for tankyrases in influencing at multiple levels the interphase dynamics of the microtubule network and the subcellular distribution of related polarity signals. These results encourage the further exploration of tankyrase inhibitors as therapeutic tools to oppose dissemination and metastasis of cancer cells.

      The systematic translation of cancer genomic data into knowledge of tumor biol. and therapeutic possibilities remains challenging. Such efforts should be greatly aided by robust preclin. model systems that reflect the genomic diversity of human cancers and for which detailed genetic and pharmacol. annotation is available. Here we describe the Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia (CCLE): a compilation of gene expression, chromosomal copy no. and massively parallel sequencing data from 947 human cancer cell lines. When coupled with pharmacol. profiles for 24 anticancer drugs across 479 of the cell lines, this collection allowed identification of genetic, lineage, and gene-expression-based predictors of drug sensitivity. The generation of genetic predictions of drug response in the preclin. setting and their incorporation into cancer clin. trial design could speed the emergence of personalized' therapeutic regimens.

      A comprehensive transcriptional portrait of human cancer cell lines
      Klijn, Christiaan; Durinck, Steffen; Stawiski, Eric W.; Haverty, Peter M.; Jiang, Zhaoshi; Liu, Hanbin; Degenhardt, Jeremiah; Mayba, Oleg; Gnad, Florian; Liu, Jinfeng; Pau, Gregoire; Reeder, Jens; Cao, Yi; Mukhyala, Kiran; Selvaraj, Suresh K.; Yu, Mamie; Zynda, Gregory J.; Brauer, Matthew J.; Wu, Thomas D.; Gentleman, Robert C.; Manning, Gerard; Yauch, Robert L.; Bourgon, Richard; Stokoe, David; Modrusan, Zora; Neve, Richard M.; de Sauvage, Frederic J.; Settleman, Jeffrey; Seshagiri, Somasekar; Zhang, Zemin
      Nature Biotechnology (2015), 33 (3), 306-312CODEN: NABIF9; ISSN:1087-0156. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Tumor-derived cell lines have served as vital models to advance our understanding of oncogene function and therapeutic responses. Although substantial effort has been made to define the genomic constitution of cancer cell line panels, the transcriptome remains understudied. Here we describe RNA sequencing and single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) array anal. of 675 human cancer cell lines. We report comprehensive analyses of transcriptome features including gene expression, mutations, gene fusions and expression of non-human sequences. Of the 2,200 gene fusions catalogued, 1,435 consist of genes not previously found in fusions, providing many leads for further investigation. We combine multiple genome and transcriptome features in a pathway-based approach to enhance prediction of response to targeted therapeutics. Our results provide a valuable resource for studies that use cancer cell lines.

      High-Resolution Enabled TMT 8-plexing
      Werner, Thilo; Becher, Isabelle; Sweetman, Gavain; Doce, Carola; Savitski, Mikhail M.; Bantscheff, Marcus
      Analytical Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 84 (16), 7188-7194CODEN: ANCHAM; ISSN:0003-2700. (American Chemical Society)
      Isobaric mass tag-based quant. proteomics strategies such as iTRAQ and TMT utilize reporter ions in the low-mass range of tandem MS spectra for relative quantification. The no. of samples that can be compared in a single expt. (multiplexing) is limited by the no. of different reporter ions that can be generated by differential stable isotope incorporation (15N, 13C) across the reporter and the mass balancing parts of the reagents. Here, we demonstrate that a higher multiplexing rate can be achieved by utilizing the 6 mDa mass difference between 15N- and 13C-contg. reporter fragments, in combination with high-resoln. mass spectrometry. Two variants of the TMT127 and TMT129 reagents are available; these are distinguished by the position and the nature of the incorporated stable isotope in the reporter portions of the labels (TMT127L, 12C8H1615N1+; TMT127H, 12C713C1H1614N1+; TMT129L, 12C613C2H1615N1+; and TMT129H, 12C513C3H1614N1+). We demonstrate that these variants can be baseline-resolved in Orbitrap Elite higher-energy collision-induced dissocn. spectra recorded with a 96 ms transient enabling comparable dynamic range, precision, and accuracy of quantification as 1 Da spaced reporter ions. The increased multiplexing rate enabled detn. of inhibitor potencies in chemoproteomic kinase assays covering a wider range of compd. concns. in a single expt., compared to conventional 6-plex TMT-based assays.

      Ion Coalescence of Neutron Encoded TMT 10-Plex Reporter Ions
      Werner, Thilo; Sweetman, Gavain; Savitski, Maria Faelth; Mathieson, Toby; Bantscheff, Marcus; Savitski, Mikhail M.
      Analytical Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2014), 86 (7), 3594-3601CODEN: ANCHAM; ISSN:0003-2700. (American Chemical Society)
      Isobaric mass tag-based quant. proteomics strategies such as iTRAQ and TMT utilize reporter ions in the low mass range of tandem MS spectra for relative quantification. The recent extension of TMT multiplexing to 10 conditions has been enabled by utilizing neutron encoded tags with reporter ion m/z differences of 6 mDa. The baseline resoln. of these closely spaced tags is possible due to the high resolving power of current day mass spectrometers. In this work we evaluated the performance of the TMT10 isobaric mass tags on the Q Exactive Orbitrap mass spectrometers for the first time and demonstrated comparable quantification accuracy and precision to what can be achieved on the Orbitrap Elite mass spectrometers. However, we discovered, upon anal. of complex proteomics samples on the Q Exactive Orbitrap mass spectrometers, that the proximate TMT10 reporter ion pairs become prone to coalescence. The fusion of the different reporter ion signals into a single measurable entity has a detrimental effect on peptide and protein quantification. We established that the main reason for coalescence is the commonly accepted max. ion target for MS2 spectra of 1e6 on the Q Exactive instruments. The coalescence artifact was completely removed by lowering the max. ion target for MS2 spectra from 1e6 to 2e5 without any losses in identification depth or quantification quality of proteins.

        Tankyrases as drug targets
        Lehtio Lari; Chi Nai-Wen; Krauss Stefan
        The FEBS journal (2013), 280 (15), 3576-93 ISSN:.
        Tankyrase 1 and tankyrase 2 are poly(ADP-ribosyl)ases that are distinguishable from other members of the enzyme family by the structural features of the catalytic domain, and the presence of a sterile Î±-motif multimerization domain and an ankyrin repeat protein-interaction domain. Tankyrases are implicated in a multitude of cellular functions, including telomere homeostasis, mitotic spindle formation, vesicle transport linked to glucose metabolism, Wnt-Î²-catenin signaling, and viral replication. In these processes, tankyrases interact with target proteins, catalyze poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation, and regulate protein interactions and stability. The proposed roles of tankyrases in disease-relevant cellular processes have made them attractive drug targets. Recently, several inhibitors have been identified. The selectivity and potency of these small molecules can be rationalized by how they fit within the NAD(+)-binding groove of the catalytic domain. Some molecules bind to the nicotinamide subsite, such as generic diphtheria toxin-like ADP-ribosyltransferase inhibitors, whereas others bind to a distinct adenosine subsite that diverges from other diphtheria toxin-like ADP-ribosyltransferases and confers specificity. A highly potent dual-site inhibitor is also available. Within the last few years, tankyrase inhibitors have proved to be useful chemical probes and potential lead compounds, especially for specific cancers.

        Tankyrase function at telomeres, spindle poles, and beyond
        Hsiao, Susan J.; Smith, Susan
        Biochimie (2008), 90 (1), 83-92CODEN: BICMBE; ISSN:0300-9084. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Telomeres have special needs; they require distinct mechanisms for their protection, replication, and sepn. at mitosis. A dedicated six-subunit protein complex termed shelterin attends to these needs. But shelterin cannot do it alone and often relies on recruits from other cellular locales. One such recruit is tankyrase 1, a poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase that is brought to telomeres by the shelterin DNA binding subunit TRF1, where it functions in telomere length regulation and sister chromatid sepn. An understanding of how tankyrase 1 functions at telomeres has been confounded by its complexity; it localizes to multiple subcellular sites, it has many diverse binding partners, and it has a closely related homolog (tankyrase 2) with which it may functionally overlap. This review summarizes our current knowledge of tankyrases focusing on their localization, binding partners, and function.

        Tankyrases: Structure, Function and Therapeutic Implications in Cancer
        Haikarainen, Teemu; Krauss, Stefan; Lehtio, Lari
        Current Pharmaceutical Design (2014), 20 (41), 6472-6488CODEN: CPDEFP; ISSN:1381-6128. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
        A review. Several cellular signaling pathways are regulated by ADP-ribosylation, a posttranslational modification catalyzed by members of the ARTD superfamily. Tankyrases are distinguishable from the rest of this family by their unique domain organization, notably the sterile alpha motif responsible for oligomerization and ankyrin repeats mediating protein-protein interactions. Tankyrases are involved in various cellular functions, such as telomere homeostasis, Wnt/Î² -catenin signaling, glucose metab., and cell cycle progression. In these processes, Tankyrases regulate the interactions and stability of target proteins by poly (ADP-ribosyl)ation. Modified proteins are subsequently recognized by the E3 ubiquitin ligase RNF146, poly-ubiquitinated and predominantly guided to 26S proteasomal degrdn. Several small mol. inhibitors have been described for Tankyrases; they compete with the co-substrate NAD+ for binding to the ARTD catalytic domain. The recent, highly potent and selective inhibitors possess several properties of lead compds. and can be used for proof-of-concept studies in cancer and other Tankyrase linked diseases.

        Tankyrase-targeted therapeutics: expanding opportunities in the PARP family
        Riffell, Jenna L.; Lord, Christopher J.; Ashworth, Alan
        Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2012), 11 (12), 923-936CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) protein superfamily has wide-ranging roles in cellular processes such as DNA repair and WNT signalling. Efforts to pharmacol. target PARP enzymes have largely focused on PARP1 and the closely related PARP2, but recent work highlighting the role of another family member, tankyrase 1 (TANK1; also known as PARP5A and ARTD5), in the control of WNT signalling has fuelled interest in the development of addnl. inhibitors to target this enzyme class. Here, we discuss the biol. of tankyrases and the discovery of tankyrase-specific inhibitors. We also consider the challenges that lie ahead for the clin. development of PARP family inhibitors in general.

        Tankyrase, a poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase at human telomeres
        Smith, Susan; Giriat, Izabela; Schmitt, Anja; De Langet, Titia
        Science (Washington, D. C.) (1998), 282 (5393), 1484-1488CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Tankyrase, a protein with homol. to ankyrins and to the catalytic domain of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP), was identified and localized to human telomeres. Tankyrase binds to the telomeric protein TRF1 (telomeric repeat binding factor-1), a neg. regulator of telomere length maintenance. Like ankyrins, tankyrase contains 24 ankyrin repeats in a domain responsible for its interaction with TRF1.         Tankyrase-1 polymerization of poly(ADP-ribose) is required for spindle structure and function
        Chang, Paul; Coughlin, Margaret; Mitchison, Timothy J.
        Nature Cell Biology (2005), 7 (11), 1133-1139CODEN: NCBIFN; ISSN:1465-7392. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Poly(ADP-ribose) (PAR) is a large, neg. charged post-translational modification that is produced by polymn. of NAD+ by PAR polymerases (PARPs). There are at least 18 PARPs in the human genome, several of which have functions that are unknown. PAR modifications are dynamic; PAR structure depends on the balance between synthesis and hydrolysis by PAR glycohydrolase. We previously found that PAR is enriched in vertebrate somatic-cell mitotic spindles and demonstrated a requirement for PAR in the assembly of Xenopus egg ext. spindles. Here, we knockdown all characterized PARPs using RNA interference (RNAi), and identify tankyrase-1 as the PARP that is required for mitosis. Tankyrase-1 localizes to mitotic spindle poles, to telomeres and to the Golgi app. Tankyrase-1 RNAi was recently shown to result in mitotic arrest, with abnormal chromosome distributions and spindle morphol. obsd. - data that is interpreted as evidence of post-anaphase arrest induced by failure of telomere sepn. We show that tankyrase-1 RNAi results in pre-anaphase arrest, with intact sister-chromatid cohesion. We also demonstrate a requirement for tankyrase-1 in the assembly of bipolar spindles, and identify the spindle-pole protein NuMA as a substrate for covalent modification by tankyrase-1.

        Fancy, Stephen P. J.; Harrington, Emily P.; Yuen, Tracy J.; Silbereis, John C.; Zhao, Chao; Baranzini, Sergio E.; Bruce, Charlotte C.; Otero, Jose J.; Huang, Eric J.; Nusse, Roel; Franklin, Robin J. M.; Rowitch, David H.

        A review.
